headline: Slow Cooker Homemade Beans
description: These slow cooker beans are simmered with bacon, onion, brown sugar, molasses, and mustard until soft and flavorful for a main course or side dish.
name: Slow Cooker Homemade Beans
recipeIngredient: 3 cups dry navy beans, soaked overnight or boiled for one hour
6 slices thick cut bacon, cut into 1 inch pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Drain soaking liquid from beans; place them in a slow cooker.
Stir bacon, onion, ketchup, water, brown sugar, molasses, mustard, and salt into beans until well mixed.
Cover and cook on Low for 8 to 10 hours; stir occasionally if possible.

review.reviewBody: The receipt was good, but to prevent having hard beans, after soaking overnight, drain then add fresh water and boil on the stove for 40minutes before putting them in the slow cooker.

This recipe is delicious. I cannot wait to make it again. Yum! I decided to make this last minute so I boiled the beans for an hour and added a bit more water to recipe. I also substituted half of the ketchup with chili sauce.
This recipe needed 2 cups more of water. Had to cook on slow in my slow cooker for over 12 hrs. Would not make again.

First off, never add the salt or other ingredients until beans are 95% cooked.(You could add a ham hock or seasoned meat about halfway through cooking though) I see a lot of people saying the beans are hard. It's not the recipe's fault. Certain ingredients stop the beans from cooking and they will always be hard. Some beans are old and take 3 hours to get tender, fresh beans maybe take and hour. Test a bean or two first. Always pour off the first batch of cooking water,(supposed to get rid of some of the gas) Not my fav recipe but it is good.
Awesome!! It's become a demanded thing in my house
Taste wise, these are great. However, I started soaking them 16 hours before cooking and I still had to cook them on high in order to get the beans to cook. Probably will not make again.

Cooking this recipe for 2 days is ridiculous! Soaked the beans for 12 hours on Friday, started cooking in slow cooker at 9:00am on Saturday and here it is 1:30 on Sunday and they still aren’t done! Absurd!

I made a few changes and my family thought the results were fantastic:
- 4 cups dry navy beans instead of 3 cups
- 1/2 cup brown sugar instead of 1 cup
- added 1/4 cup (real) maple syrup
- added 1 Tbsp Worcestershire Sauce
- reduced the ketchup by 25%
- soaked the beans for 8 hrs. and then boiled them for 45 minutes.
- added salt at the very end (helps beans to soften)
- thick bacon, yes, but also additional pork added (your choice what cuts)
A solid recipe!!

I did find that the beans were quite hard after following the directions and cooking for about 24 hrs. I wasn't gong to give up what I had started (after I heard that the beans were old via a website). I added about 2 cups of water and what a change the beans had. Nice and soft just what you want. It seems the answer is more water. 
"How can you tell if dried beans are old" I have no idea.
ps: a bought a smoked jowl instead of bacon. Same taste 1/4 of the price of bacon.
Really good. I add a bit of barbecue sauce as well. Definitely soak the beans overnight first.

I use a full bag of beans before I realized it said 3 cups and it came out fabulously!
Loved it and it’s my go to beans recipe!
A little too sweet, I learned to boil the beans for 1 hr instead of soaking, works great
After soaking them overnight I cooked them on high for 8 hrs and they were still kinda hard. Wondering if there something I could do to soften them more? Not as sweet as other recipes too.

I have tried twice now. The sauce behind this is good, but the beans did not cook through. I have soaked them over night both times, and I also boiled the beans for an hour before adding to slow cooker. The first time I did the recipe exactly as written, the second time I slow cooked them on medium for 11 hours! I will not do this recipe again. That’s six cups worth of wasted beans when this was all said and done.

Absolutely one of the best “fail-proof” recipes! Tastes just like my grandmothers baked beans - but much easier. Please just try this recipe if you do not want to “babysit” your beans in the oven. Thank you so much for this recipe! We live it!
I didn't read the reviews first, my beans were hard. I knew they tasted good, so I put them in the food processor with some tahini sauce and made a bean dip. New recipe!
Loved ‘em! Instead of soaking the beans overnight I used my instant pot to cook them first for 35 minutes for a q pound bag.

I was all ready to love this but it simply didn't work for anyone eating it. Cooked exactly as the recipe states, you end up with too firm a bean and, although the recipe pictures look very saucy, it has so little sauce compared to bean that it was somewhat dry for those eating it. Perhaps soaking them overnight instead of boiling the beans would have made a difference in texture but, short of doubling the sauce, this remains a thin and scarce sauce.

Well this recipe was so easy, and I latticed bacon strips on top, and baked in my SHARP microwave convection oven on mix bake at 350 degrees in a dutch oven. they were perfect BBQ beans to go with my bbq chix thighs and Dad's creamy cucumber salad recipe on this site.

I made these beans for a family cookout. Followed the recipe except I did half the salt because there's salt in ketchup.
They turned out delicious! Taste like they've baked slowly in an oven bean pot! I will definitely make these again!

I thought it was too "ketchupy". I added 1 cup of barbeque sauce, and increased the molasses, brown sugar and ground mustard slightly, which improved the taste somewhat. But the next time I want baked beans, I sticking with Bushes Best Original Baked Beans.
This was a huge hit with my Sunday Brunch group.

I reduced the ketchup to 1 cup, overnighted Great Northern Beans, and then instant potted them for 1/2 hour (too long. Should have been 15 minutes). And they were beyond excellent!! Best beans ever. This is definitely a keeper and will make often!

After soaking my beans for a couple hours, I cooked them on low right in my crockpot - overnight. Add plenty of water before cooking. I also chop some garlic and add that too. In the morning, check to make sure the beans are done (squash a bean between your fingers). Then I drain & reserve the liquid. Smash some of the beans with a masher and add all the other ingredients. Go easy on the salt and sugar. I fry some bacon, drain it and saute the onion in the grease, then add to the beans. I like prepared mustard instead of powdered. Use the reserved liquid instead of plain water, but don't overdo it. Check for thickness. Also, I prefer tomato paste and just a dash of ketchup. Cook on low several hours, check for water and leave the lid ajar a little to thicken. Yummy !
I had the same problem. Beans not cooked What I ended up doing was putting them in the pressure cooker added beef broth and cooked them on high for 40 minutes.

Anybody that cooks at all knows you cook dried beans by themselves, for sure no salt in the water until they are tender. Then put the dish together. I learned this the hard way too. Ruined several dishes with hard beans until I read somewhere that you never cook dried beans with salt in the water. Just water until they are tender. Then add the rest of the ingredients. Works every time.

Excellent but the beans were crunchy. I will use canned beans next time. I think the beans might have been old. I may soak them next time and then cook them for 1 hour. If they aren't soft enough, I will throw the beans out.

Great recipe if you like your beans El Dente.
Followed the recipe to a T , cooked it for 9 hours and the beans were crunchy. I will say that the sauce was good , the bacon and onions were good but the beans were not cooked . A lot of them were still white. I even cooked it on high for the last hour and a half. I usually read the reviews before I fixed a recipe but I was lazy and saw it had 4 stars and went ahead. Big mistake.
don't follow the recipe exactly - I had beans cooking for 15 hours and they were still hard - wish I had read the reviews before I cooked them for 8 hours

In order to save time I cooked the beans for 40 minutes with water in Instapot. Then sautéed onion with bacon for about 5 minutes and added beans along with rest of ingredients to slow cooker for about 2 hours for flavors to mesh. Awesome recipe.

This recipe is a good start, but we strongly recommend cutting the brown sugar by at least 1/2 cup. 1/3 cup of will be sufficient for many people. Use more fresh garlic and onion and skip the dried. Go a little easy on the liquid smoke.

I cut the ketchup to just under a cup, used coconut sugar instead of cane, and added about a teaspoon of hickory smoked flavoring. I slow cooked it on high for twelve hours, and then on low for ten hours.

It's the best baked beans I've ever eaten, better even than Mom's! :D
My kids devoured the whole pot & have asked me to make them again.

It was a bit too sweet on the first go around. So I cut back on the brown sugar and used only a third of what this recipe called for. I did not change the amount of molasses. 

That being said I liked the recipe a lot.
Listen to some of the other comments and soaked the beans overnight then boiled in the morning before putting them in the slow cooker came out great delicious!!!
Beautiful flavor......this is a keeper!

Following suggestions of others I soaked the beans overnight and then removed the water, added fresh water brought to a boil and simmered for an hour. Pretty much followed the recipe after that except adding a bit more molasses and slightly less brown sugar. I checked after 8 hours and the beans were perfect. I did continue cooking for another hour which dried up the sauce a bit. So after 8 hours these beans are perfect and delicious !!!!

I followed the recipe completely, but the only thing I didn’t like was some of the beans were still a little hard. The recipe states, “soak beans overnight OR boil for an hour.” What I should of done was soak overnight and boil too. So what I ended up doing was when there was 2 hrs left I turned my crockpot up to high and then added an extra 1hr 45min and the beans turned out great, but there were still scattered beans a little hard. The recipe was very easy to put together and make.

I made the mistake of adding too much water. At the end, I had to transfer it to the stove to reduce the liquid. I skipped the ketchup (allergic) and used half the brown sugar. I added the salt at the end along with half a teaspoon of ground smoked chipotle peppers & a quarter cup of apple cider vinegar. I think I doubled the ground mustard as well. I look forward to having these in my freezer to pull out on chilly mornings for a lunch that warms me up on several levels!

super flavor

made as is - and beans remained uncooked. read the other reviews - so added the ketchup and salt in the last hour. soaked beans for 2 days first. turned out great.

Way too sweet. Soaked the beans for about 14 hours. Cooked it in my slow cooker all day...about 12 hours on high. Beans still harder than I would like it. Tempted to throw out because its so sweet but instead will freeze it into small single servings as I don't believe in wasting food.
I have made it several times, just like mom made. Great for BBQ's or potlucks.
This came out too liquidy and really sweet...too sweet really, and I had omitted the molasses because I didn’t have any. Can’t imagine how sweet it’d be otherwise. Wouldn’t make this again.
this recipe is super easy and is extremely delicious! this is my go-to baked beans recipe!

I added the whole 24-ounce bottle of catsup and reduced the water to about a half cup Instead of bacon a used a full pound of diced Taylor Ham Pork Roll (Yay New Jersey!!). I finished it off on the stovetop to let some of the liquid evaporate. Yum!!
Delicious. Very flavorful. Bit “hit” with my family.

Flavors work but you shouldn't add anything with salt to beans until they are cooked. The beans will never get to the creamy texture you want if you do. I wouldn't recommend this recipe. It's like a bad joke to cook something for hours that smells good only to find out that the texture is terrible.

I'm giving this three stars only because it took 10 hours on high! I wish I had read the reviews before putting everything in the slow cooker! If I make it again I would definitely boil the beans first! It is good taste wise.

This recipe is amazing BUT I always add HALF of the amount of ketchup, otherwise the beans are way too thick & sweet. Make sure you soak your beans overnight and after cooking with this recipe they will be fully cooked.

Sometimes when I make this recipe I add maple syrup & liquid smoke sauce... definitely recommend!
I would make this again but I'm not a fan of bacon in everything
Great receipe...my beans were not pre-soaked or boiled long enough so I had to remove and boil the put back in the sauce but turned out good. Next time I will prep my beans better
Omg first time bean maker. So delicious thanks!!
Good but don’t salt till finished cooking ,added a 1/2 cup of tomato juice at the end to loosen.
Making today with a pork hock
Absolutely delicious. I only put in half the amount of brown sugar since that was all I had on hand. They were still very good.

I love this recipe! I have made this so many times and always get rave reviews. The best tip for this is to soak the beans overnight in cold water and then boil for an hour in the morning. You can combine all of the other ingredients into a bowl and dump everything in the slow cooker. However, do not add the salt. There is enough in the bacon and it can make the skins tough and not cook thoroughly. I also cook for an hour on high before turning it to low. It never fails. It can take 9 hours, but is SO worth it! Also, I use a whole pound of bacon. It's a preference for my family, but does make a difference. Love, love, love!!!

I love this recipe! I have made this so many times and always get rave reviews. The best tip for this is to soak the beans overnight in cold water and then boil for an hour in the morning. You can combine all of the other ingredients into a bowl and dump everything in the slow cooker. However, do not add the salt. There is enough in the bacon and it can make the skins tough and not cook thoroughly. I also cook for an hour on high before turning it to low. It never fails. It can take 9 hours, but is SO worth it! Also, I use a whole pound of bacon. It's a preference for my family, but does make a difference. Love, love, love!!!

The sauce is delicious, but I wish I had seen the other reviews before I cooked it. You definitely do need to soak AND cook the beans. Otherwise they can end up kind of hard and dry, not good. But otherwise it is tasty enough that I will give it another try sometime.

Fantastic flavour but will cut sugar and/or ketchup down next time. So easy to make and fills the house with that a-mazing aroma. My grandmother’s old fashioned baked beans recipe will remain in my recipe box but this is great.

Very good, I soaked the beans overnight and I boiled them for 1/2 an hour. I think I would boil them for the full hour next time just to make sure they are rehydrated. We let them sit overnight after we made them and reheated them the next day to serve. Didn't change a thing would make again.

Loved this recipe. I followed several of the suggestions and after soaking for 12 hours I simmered the beans for an hour. Also I'm not a lover of overly sweet beans so I reduced the brown sugar by half and instead of molasses I used a cup of medium dark maple syrup. Cooked in the slow cooker on low for 10 hours and the beans just melted in the mouth. This is a great base recipe that you can endlessly tinker with and add all sorts of flavours.
Add a pound of ground beef and make it a meal...and garlic...everything tastes better with at least a couple of cloves of garlic.
The sauce was delicious, but like other people have stayed, the beans never finished cooking. I had them on low for 16 hours and they stayed slightly crunchy.

I mixed navy and pinto beans and boiled for an hour. Cooked on low for 10 hours in crockpot because beans weren't cooked enough *the pintos, of course*. Otherwise great recipe, my family has requested them several times.

Omg these are so good. It makes a lot of beans. They are so yummy. I will eat these every day until gone and make some more. Didnt remove anything or change anything but mustard...i used what i had...yellow mustard in the jar. Still very good beans

I soaked the navy beans for 8 hours overnight, drained the water. Then added fresh water and cooked 3 cups of beans for 2 hours. When the skins burst in the air, I placed them in the slow cooker with the sauce recipe. When done after 8 hours of cooking, they were still a little crunchy, but the sauce recipe is terrific! It is similar to my Dad's beans, baked in a brown pot, but can serve a crowd. I am going to cook the soaked beans half at a time so they are softer next time.

The beans were outstanding - loaded with flavor and not too sweet. I soaked them overnight and simmered them for 1 hour and 20 minutes, then in the crock for 6 hours on low and 4 on high. As recommended by others, I added the salt at the end of cooking. Beans had a delightful slightly al dente bite. This recipe was a hit! Thanks for sharing it. :)
I love making my own homemade things not only to help the environment and cut back on waste but it’s healthier than a lot of processed foods we eat today! This was a great recipe!
Great recipe. Very easy to make. I added two cloves of minced garlic and used two 16oz (1 pound) bags of Goya Navy Beans for the measurements of the ingredients.
Used a couple different types of beans for color. My favorite baked beans.

After reading reviews I decided to cook my beans half done before adding to the crock pot. I drained their liquid and followed the rest of the recipe exactly. No one in my family liked it. The beans were mostly done but there were still a few crunchy ones. This was plenty sweet but the flavor just wasn't for us. It was a waste of food and time. Just a side note, I have read a lot of other baked bean recipes and some of them say to make sure you don't use black strap molasses because of it being too bitter. I didn't have that kind so I didn't use it in this recipe but wanted to pass along the tip in case others like me are trying to find a perfect recipe for them.

Smells wonderful, I didn't have any trouble getting beans done like someone else mentioned. Boiled them for an hour before hand, however. Then, with the rest of the stuff several hours in the crock pot. After I boiled them there was no water to pour off so used the whole thing in the crock pot. Made it too soupy, but it tastes wonderful. I slightly thickened the sauce. Since I was making them for Easter dinner, I added ham chunks.
Best beans ever! I make them all the time...

Have made it a ton of times. Figured out that actually putting the beans in with water up to the top of them 6L slowcooker for overnight, then draining and adding the sauce in the morning makes perfect soft beans for supper time the next day! Have tried boiling and soaking but they were never consistent. This works wonderfully.

Super! Made for Christmas and they were a hit. I will no longer be buying canned beans. 

The only change I made is that I soaked them overnight then cooked in crockpot on low for 6-8 hours until soft. Refrigerated overnight, then put back into crockpot using the recipe, (omitting any more water) and cooked them on low another 6 hours. I was afraid they would get too mushy but they were perfect. We love the sauce!

I just read a review that talked about one of my primary disappointments with this recipe. The beans did not finish cooking completely even after soaking them overnight. I should have know to boil them before putting them in the slow cooker but it's been awhile since I cooked beans and I don't do it often enough. 
In addition, I thought it was a little unusual to add so much ketchup to a baked bean recipe but I did and I WILL NEVER ADD KETCHUP to baked beans again. Maybe if you want a barbecue type taste but NOT for a Boston Baked Bean type of dish. I cooked it per the recipe, put the beans in refrigeration overnight before even using them and then heated them up the next morning. I disliked it so much that I through out the whole pot of beans.

This recipe isn’t great.
I followed the suggestions and soaked beans overnight and boiled them to ensure they were soft enough. I didn’t add ketchup or salt until the end, put paper towel under the lid to absorb moisture and halved the brown sugar so they wouldn’t be too sweet. 
The consistency is great but they taste like ketchup beans! WAY too much ketchup! I added more brown sugar to try to counteract the tomato taste but it didn’t really help. Now I’m stuck with a huge container of ketchup baked beans.
I’ll be asking my mother in law for her delicious recipe to use from now on.
I have made this 5 times and it is a huge hit. I do boil the beans until soft and then throw it in the slow cooker with all ingredients and the beans are not hard at all. Love this recipe

This did NOT WORK! I soaked the beans for 18 hours, put them in the slow cooker for 6 hours with the other ingredients, still crunchy. Put it on high for another 1 1/2 hours, still crunchy. Put it in the pressure cooker for 1/2 hour, still crunchy. Have it in there for another hour, but had to make other plans for dinner due to time constraints. I Really think you need to bring it up to temp for an hour before you can bank on those beans getting cooked. This recipe doesn't deliver.
My family loved it, I will make it again.

The recipe says soak OR boil I chose to soak the beans then put it all together in the crock pot and cooked for at least 8 hours. The beans never cooked we even tried to put them in the oven the next day for 1.5 hour still did not cook. The recipe should be revised to read SOAK AND THEN BOIL. On a positive note the liquid was delicious.
Everyone loved them.
perfect, old fashioned, traditional baked beans. Yummy! it's my go to recipe!

I followed the recipe...boiled my beans for an hour before putting it in my crockpot with the other ingrediants...i cooked it on low all night which ended up being 12 hours...my beans never softened...kinda bummed, this was supposed to go with me to a bbq today...
Couldn't eat them, followed recipe exactly and even cooked for 2 more hours. They never cooked tender enough to eat, will never make again!! Would give a minus 10 if I could!!!!!

I followed advice from other reviewers and soaked the beans for 15 hours, boiled them on simmer for another hour, and did not add the salt or ketchup until after the beans were soft in the slow cooker. The only changes I made to the recipe were reducing the brown sugar by half, and adding a small can of stewed tomatoes which I had puréed. They were really tasty and good for a group - I made the recipe for a group of 10 and had some left overs. Caution with cooking time: I started on "High" and had to stop the cooking time to keep beans from getting mushy. Will cook longer on "Low" next time. I think this recipe has more nutrition in it than the recipes that call for tinned beans. Thanks for the recipe.
I have made this several times and it is great!

Very good. I would make it again. But probably would cut down on the sugar a bit. It was a little too sweet for my taste. I didn't soak my beans overnight, just boiled them for one hour before putting them in the slow cooker.

Please change the instructions for this recipe do that the salty, sweet, and acidic ingredients are added after the beans are cooked . My beans stayed hard after many many hours on the crock pot. Now I've learned that salt and acid in tomato based sauces (like ketchup) cause the beans to stay hard. Then I read some of the reviews and found that others had the same problem even though they gave this recipe 5 stars. It doesn't matter how good the flavor is if the texture is terrible. This was the top recipe that came up on my Google search, but the instructions need fixing so that more people don't end up with crunchy beans.
Love 'em! Will make again.

Good sauce. I used canned great northern beans because I didn't have time to soak and boil them per other reviews s. I drained and rinsed them really well. Also only used 1 cup water because I wanted to sauce to be thicker. They were a hit!
I used canned beans and it was a crowd-pleaser. Since the beans were already cooked, I used only 1 cup of water. I used BBQ sauce for half of the ketchup & only 2/3 C of brown sugar.
These are some of the best beans I've ever had and very easy.

This was my first time making beans from scratch and while the flavor was great (although a bit too sweet and I halved the sugar) my beans didn't turn out too well. I soaked them overnight and then boiled for an hour before adding all the other ingredients and after a couple of hours they become mushy. My beans ended up looking like refried beans but tasting like bbq baked beans. lol. I may try again but maybe not boil my beans before cooking.

I highly recommend these! They're GREAT!! Easy to make, delicious and, for me, taste better cold. I've found cooking the beans on the stove works better. Use a bigger pan and fill with water, - don't just cover the beans.
They turned out great. I loved these beans, but they do take much longer than the recipe states. I'll make these again but start them early in the morning or maybe even the night before.

I always like to read the reviews and make suggested changes that are to my liking. So as previous reviewers commented, I soaked the beans over night (12 hours) and then boiled them for an hour in water without salt. This definitely helped soften them. I don't like beans too sweet so used half the brown sugar, and also halved the ketchup with tomatoe puree. If you do this, you may want to add about a quarter cup of more liquid (going to try burbon next time for kicks). These were going with smoked ribs, so I was lucky and had some homemade smoked bacon in the fridge to use to give it more the BBQ taste. Next time if I just have regular bacon, I might add a tablespoon of liquid smoke for the outdoors taste. But that is just a preference. I also fried the bacon with the onions so that I could remove some of the grease before adding it to the pot for the full cooking time. These are just some personal preferences. This recipe is bang on and can easily be added to depending on your tastes and eaters. Excellent base recipe. Thanks for sharing.
I doubled this recipe for a large group of people, did not use the bacon, it took 24 hrs for the beans to soften in the crock pot. The beans were delicious and everyone at the party loved them...
